utterances: Egyptians believe the treaty negotiated at Camp David cost former President Anwar Sadat his life.
He was assassinated two years after he signed it, and since then only Jordon has signed a similar accord with the Israelis.
Egypt spent years overcoming Arab anger at what many people call a betrayal of the Palestinian cause.
That anger seemed to resurface late last year as Israeli warplanes pounded the Gaza Strip.
(Soundbite of protest)
From Jakarta to Istanbul, protestors condemned the Jewish state.
But running a close second as an object of vilification was Egypt.
(Soundbite of protest)
Egyptians were also angry.

Truck driver Rafat Imam(ph), sitting at a roadside cafe on the way to the Gaza border, said a few days after the Israeli offensive began that he was disgusted with his government for failing to help the people of Gaza.
(Through translator) It's shameful.
And that's not just my opinion.
Everyone feels that.
What's happening to the Palestinians is wrong.
They're our brothers at the end of the day and Egypt could do many things to help them.

But Egypt ignored the pressure and kept the border closed to all but emergency medical cases and supplies, explaining that it could not just throw the border open without violating the Camp David accord.
Analysts said the government had decided it could live with domestic dissent and regional condemnation, but it could not afford to break the treaty with Israel.
Three decades into what has frequently been referred to as a cold peace, the Camp David accord has taken root.
There are trade ties, including the sale of Egyptian natural gas to Israel.
And there's also the nearly $2 billion in U.S.
foreign aid that has flowed to Cairo each year, second only to the amount given to Israel.
There are also close contacts as Egypt tries to broker a truce between Israel and Hamas, and a prisoner swap.
Analysts Assander Imrani(ph) at the International Crisis Group says if Egypt was once a reluctant partner in this accord, that's no longer the case.
If Camp David didn't exist, it would be - we would be dealing with a completely different region.
We would probably have Egypt behaving more like Iran.
It's almost unthinkable, you know, to think of the consequences of Camp David not being there.
But Imrani says Egypt-Israeli relations are likely to face a new test as the hawkish Benjamin Netanyahu puts together a new Israeli government.
His foreign minister is expected to Avigdor Lieberman, the right-wing leader who said last year that President Hosni Mubarak could go to hell.

The choice of Avigdor Lieberman adds insult to injury in that Lieberman has a history of having made other remarks, certainly racist ones, but also I think at one point he said - he suggested that the (unintelligible) should be nuked.
But it's going to be difficult for the Egyptians to deal with him.

If the past 30 years are any guide, however, Egypt will find a way to keep up its end of the Camp David accord, the improbable, unpopular chilly peace that has been a fact of life for more than a generation now.
Peter Kenyon, NPR News, Cairo.
Time for your letters.
And a number of you wrote in about a report we aired yesterday, a grizzly story, which, as we said, listeners could find very unsettling.
It's about a new book which details the investigation of a lampshade found at a rummage sale in New Orleans.
Genetic testing determined that the shade is made of human skin.
The book considers the possibility that the lampshade might have a history in the Holocaust.

Well, Senator Specter, you shouldn't want a judge who will sit at this table and who will tell you that she will reverse a decision without listening to arguments and without reading briefs and without talking to colleagues.
E.J.
Dionne, is this more than just a regular charade that we see when nominees go before the Senate?
Did we learn anything about this nominee and these hearings that we didn't know before?
Well, Roger Gordon of Washington, D.C.
was one of many who were unsettled.
He called the story, the most appalling thing I have heard on the radio in many years.

As a black American who has studied the history of his people, I thought I was inured to such things, but the casual curiosity, the nonchalance, the utter lack of horror that the book's author and previous owners showed at having such an abomination in their possession moved me to tears.
So, thank you for that terrible tale.
It reminded me never to become used to human suffering.
Our story about returning unwanted gifts raised a very different set of concerns for some of you.
We reported that Amazon is patenting a way for people who are about to receive a gift that they probably don't want, to exchange it before it's ever shipped.
Users could create a filter for certain gift senders.
If Amazon actually puts this into practice, it would save the company a lot of money in handling returns.
Well, Nancy Campbell of Saint Louis writes, have you seen a drive for Toys For Tots or something similar for those who have nothing?
If you really don't like Aunt Mildred's gift, then ask her to donate the money to a charitable organization where it will be put to some good use.
You probably don't need what it is you think you want anyway.
I'm embarrassed for our society, and I use that term loosely, has degenerated to the point that people feel that it is right to preemptively return a gift.
Shame on all of us.
And Lloyd Arnold of Winterville, North Carolina, sent this warning to anyone who might try such a gift filter.
He writes, sooner or later, a hacker will break into Amazon and send your gift filter to Wikileaks.
Don't send us your gift filter, but do send us your thoughts about the program.
Go to NPR.org and click on Contact Us at the bottom of the page.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Michele Norris.
And I'm Melissa Block.
A pretty gloomy jobs picture emerged today.
The monthly snapshot for June showed the loss of 125,000 jobs.
Much of that from temporary workers ending their work on the 2010 census.
President Obama pointed to the sixth straight month of job growth in the private sector.
We're heading in the right direction, he said, but not fast enough.
We still have a great deal of work to do to repair the economy and get the American people back to work.
Well, here to talk through this economic news and more, our regular Friday political commentators, columnist E.J.
Dionne of The Washington Post and David Brooks in the New York Times.
Welcome back.
Mr.
E.J.
DIONNE (Columnist, The Washington Post): Thank you.
Good to be here.
Great deal of work to do, the president says there.
David Brooks, do you think this economic recovery has stalled in a jobless way?
Would you support calls, as we're hearing, for a second round of stimulus spending?
No.
In a word.
You know, I hear those calls, I read them out of in my own newspaper.
And the calls have some plausibility, the people have a theory and they have economic models to back them up.
If you imagine you have what they call a multiplier, you'll get more jobs with government spending.
But right I'm a little skeptical.
And I'm a skeptical, first, because right now the fiscal and monetary spigots are wide open.
We're not seeing a whole bunch of job growth.
And, second, we're in a specific moment of high debt.
And when you increase debt at moments like these to deficits spent to try to create jobs, you don't give people confidence, you freak everybody out.
And small businesses are not going to hire because they're going to think big tax increases are in the future and they'll know this growth isn't real.
And so in this circumstance I just don't think that kind of spending works.
And picking up on David's point there, E.J., how can Democrats make the case to voters that the first stimulus package worked if we are in fact still looking at nearly 10 percent unemployment?
Well, first of all, I always like it when David channels Herbert Hoover.
I mean, Herbert Hoover basically said we have to cut deficits in order to create confidence so we got the economy moving.
And that worked out very badly.
I think these numbers make an overwhelming case for goosing the economy a little more because the fiscal spigots are not open.
State governments are raising taxes, they're laying off workers, teachers are going to be laid off.
That's going to hurt the overall economy.
And I think Democrats should be pushing a lot harder than they are for the fiscal stimulus.
I think in terms of the overall economy, I think David Leonhardt, David's colleague on The New York Times had it right.
He said the overall picture isn't so much of a double dip recession as it is of a badly wounded economy recovering at a slow pace.
And I think, to answer your question, it's not good for the Democrats.
I think I feel personally gloomier about their chances now than I did a month ago for a variety of reasons.
But these numbers are a part of that.
David Brooks, are you going to take that Herbert Hoover analogy sitting down?
No, I'm not, I'm outraged.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Listen, I don't think we should just have austerity.

I think this is a moment to think fundamentally about the shape of the economy, have some fundamental tax reform, have some infrastructure spending, but not do it in a fizzy way where you're trying to goose short-term growth because it'll just scare everybody.
So we need a fundamental growth agenda, but not and not just austerity.
Let's move on to something else.
We also saw and heard this week the confirmation hearings for Supreme Court nominee Elena Kagan.
And we heard what has become by now very familiar complaints from senators about a nominee who would not show her hand.
And let's listen to an exchange between Senator Arlen Specter - former Republican, now Democrat - and the nominee Elena Kagan.
The kinds of questions I have just raised, you wouldn't answer anything and perhaps you haven't...
…and they tend to talk about nothing of any consequence and…
